text:
Grand Concourse (Mott Ave.), north from and including East 153rd Street. On the left is Franz Sigel Park, and on the extreme right appears part of the Melrose freight yard of the New York Central Railroad.

1915.
title: Bronx: Grand Concourse - 153rd Street (East)

text:
Grand Concourse, south from East 161st Street, showing (right) Franz Sigel Park extending to East 153rd Street. On the left appears Sheridan Ave. and the Melrose yard of the New York Central Railroad which is spanned by the East 153rd Street bridge. Note, under construction, on the block bounded by East 159th and 158th Streets, the large 6-story Thomas Garden Apartments, and south of it, the rectangular Fleischmann Company laboratory. The wooded park area from East 161st to 158th Streets is now (1938) occupied by the New Bronx County Court House. Also shown is a panoramic view southward with the Hell Gate Bridge across the East River visible in the distant left background, and Manhattan discernible in the right background. The vantage-point is the 10-story Concourse Plaza building, at the N.E. corner of Grand Concourse and East 161st Street.

May 1926.

Brown Brothers.
title: Bronx: Grand Concourse - 153rd Street (East)

text: Grand Concourse, between East 153rd and East 156th Streets, viewing north toward the latter across Franz Sigel Park. At the N. E. corner of East 156th Street is a six-story house, the Alexandria, nearing completion. On the cleared area, where side of sign is visible, were later erected a group of modern apartment buildings. View 2 is east across the clearance which inclines toward Sheridan Avenue. Shown, too, are the Melrose yards of the New York Central Railroad. View 3 shows the rears of the apartment buildings that were later erected on the site, the view being northwest from Sheridan Avenue, near East 153rd Street (the Morgan Steam Laundry). P. L. Sperr  Views 1,2: May 16, 1928 View 3: June 9, 1940
title: Bronx: Grand Concourse - 153rd Street (East)

title: Bronx: Grand Concourse - 153rd Street (East)

text:
East 153rd Street (running from fore to background), east from Grand Concourse (Mott Ave.), showing the bridge across the Melrose car yards of the New York Central Railroad. The 1-story garage on the left bears No. 672 Grand Concourse and is at the N.E. corner of East 153rd Street.

July 7, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Bronx: 153rd Street (East) - Grand Concourse

text:
(1)
Grand Concourse (Mott Ave.), north from a point between East 153rd and East 156th Streets, showing in the center background, the Bronx County Court House from East 158th to 161st Streets and extending west to Walton Ave. Also shown is part of Franz Siegel Park.
April 30, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, as seen from the park, at East 156th Street.
April 30, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

(3)
The same, an additional view.
June 7, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.

title: Bronx: Grand Concourse - 153rd Street (East)

text:
(1)

700 Grand Concourse (Mott Ave.), east side, north of the N.E. corner of East 153rd Street, showing the Morgan Laundry. The view is in a southerly direction from Franz Siegel Park.

July 7, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

Part of the same. Note the shack under the billboard midway between East 156th and 153rd Streets. The laundry buildings appear across the billboard.

April 30, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Bronx: Grand Concourse - 153rd Street (East)

title: Bronx: Grand Concourse - 153rd Street (East)

text:
Grand Concourse (Mott Ave.), north from a point slightly south of East 153rd to and including East 156th Streets. Prominently shown is the Morgan Laundry (buildings with chimney) at No. 700 and north of it, construction work in progress on new apartment houses.

April 30, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Bronx: Grand Concourse - 153rd Street (East)

text:
Grand Concourse, at the S. E. corner of E. 153rd Street, showing excavation work in progress on the site where the Cardinal Hayes Memorial High School for Boys will be erected. Archbishop Francis J. Spellman laid the cornerstone for the new structure on November 20, 1940. For additional data see "The New York Times," November 21, 1940.

June 9, 1940

P. L. Sperr
